7.text:
I feel terribly privileged when 
I'm handling human brains.

12.text:
This tissue is something bequested 
to us for research purposes

19.text:
and it's an honour to be able to handle 
the tissue and meet that bequest.

37.text:
My name's Steve Gentleman. I'm the Professor of 
Neuropathology at Imperial College, London

42.text:
and one of my jobs is to carry out 
the diagnostic assessment

47.text:
of the brains that come in
 to our tissue bank.

56.text:
The first thing you do when 
you get the brain is to examine

59.text:
the external features of the brain 
to see if there's any clue there

62.text: as to what might've gone on.

65.text:
So you look at the surface of the brain, 
the membranes that cover the brain,

70.text: is there any evidence of any infection?

73.text:
We then look at the patterns on the surface 
of the brain at the folding to see if that's normal

79.text:
and whether there's any shrinkage 
or atrophy in any particular areas.

83.text:
Also, feel the brain to see if there's 
any softenings, because if there is a soft area

89.text:
that may indicate there 
was a stroke in that area.

92.text:
Then look at the blood vessels 
at the base of the brain

95.text:
and they will give us some 
clues as to lifestyle factors

101.text:
They may be atherosclerotic, 
or hardening of the arteries,

106.text:
due to a high fat diet or 
smoking or lack of exercise

111.text:
all may contribute to 
this type of change.

119.text: When we have a whole brain fixed in formalin,

123.text:
what will do is we will make 
a cut through the brain stem,

128.text:
which is that part of the brain 
which is quite small but very

131.text:
important in carrying out all those 
everyday functions that we all rely on

142.text:
We separate the brain stem and the 
cerebellum from the rest of the brain.

156.text:
In order to carry out the 
neuropathological examination

160.text:
in a reproducible fashion, we have to 
cut up the brain in a fairly stereotypical way.

168.text: So we use a single point for our first cut.

173.text:
We have a landmark called the mammillary body 
– it's a part of the brain involved in housekeeping functions,

180.text:
and we use that as 
our guide for the first cut

183.text:
using a rather large bread knife, if you like 
– that's what it looks like.

200.text:
and then space those out so that we can have a 
look through the whole extent of the brain

206.text:
and then to take some 
representative blocks so that we can

210.text:
follow up and look down the 
microscope at what's going on.

213.text:
And in this way we can 
build up a diagnostic report

216.text:
of what the problem was 
with that particular patient.

219.text:
And this is very important because 
the tissue then goes out to researchers

223.text:
and they need to know 
exactly what was going on.

232.text: We cut the sections using a guide

235.text:
because there are some parts of 
the brain that we need to look at

239.text:
which are quite small, so we have to 
accurately make a half-centimetre slice.

248.text:
When all the slices are 
laid out in a logical fashion

253.text: you can inspect each slice individually

256.text:
working from the front to 
the back of the brain,

259.text:
just checking that all the structures 
are as you would expect them to be,

263.text:
looking for any signs of change, 
whether it be

266.text:
in multiple sclerosis, for example, there may 
be changes in the colour of parts of the brain.

273.text:
We then have to sample 
20 specific anatomical areas

278.text:
to allow us to take them away to be stained 
and look at them down the microscope,

283.text:
to try and work out which 
pathologies are there,

287.text: because it's not always just one pathology.

290.text:
We have to make sure if there 
are multiple pathologies,

293.text:
that we write that down, and again, 
it's very important for the researcher,

297.text:
they need to know everything 
that's gone on in the brain.

303.text:
The samples we take are put 
into small plastic cassettes

307.text:
and these are then 
embedded in paraffin wax

310.text:
and the reason we do this is to get very, very 
thin slices to look at under the microscope

316.text:
we need to mount the tissue 
into something that can be cut.

319.text:
So those are cut at about six microns, 
which is very, very thin

324.text: and allows us to look at the tissue.

330.text:
I've been looking at brains for 25 years now 
and I have probably examined over a thousand.

342.text:
When I first pick up the brain,
what I'm looking at is the external features

348.text:
and, if you like, the convolutions of 
the brain are a little bit like a fingerprint

352.text: – they are unique to the individual.

355.text:
Obviously they have a very similar general structure,
but there are subtleties,

359.text: we're all slightly different in our development

361.text: so no two brains are the same,

364.text:
and indeed that applies 
to the pathology as well.

367.text: Parkinson's disease is a very well-described disease,

370.text:
but in fact the pathology you see in the brains 
of people who've had Parkinson's disease
